sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• before starting vemurafenib, confirm presence of BRAF V600E mutation in tumor specimen, perform a dermatologic evaluation, and establish baseline monitoring of ECG, electrolytes, liver enzymes, and bilirubin
  • Malignant melanoma, Unresectable, stage IIIC or metastatic, BRAF V600E mutation positive: 960 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue treatment until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity occurs
  • Malignant melanoma, Unresectable, stage IIIC or metastatic, BRAF V600E mutation positive: if vomiting occurs, do not repeat dose

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy of vemurafenib have not been established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• cutaneous malignancy, primary (new): dose modifications are not recommended
  • grade 2 (intolerable) or grade 3 toxicities: for first appearance, interrupt until grade 0 to 1, then resume at 720 mg every 12 hours; for second appearance, interrupt until grade 0 to 1, then resume at 480 mg twice daily; doses below 480 mg twice daily are not recommended
  • grade 4 toxicities: for first appearance, discontinue permanently (if clinically appropriate) or interrupt treatment until grade 0 to 1 and resume dosing at 480 mg twice daily; for second appearance, discontinue permanently; doses below 480 mg twice daily are not recommended
  • hepatic impairment (mild and moderate); no dose adjustment needed
  • QT prolongation, exceeding 500 milliseconds (grade 3 toxicity): correct electrolyte abnormalities, control cardiac risk factors for QT prolongation, and interrupt treatment until QTc is less than 500 milliseconds, then resume at a lower dose (doses below 480 mg twice daily are not recommended); if, after correction of associated risk factors, the QTc remains above 500 milliseconds and has increased more than 60 milliseconds above baseline values, then permanently discontinue vemurafenib
  • renal impairment (mild and moderate); no dose adjustment needed

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Malignant melanoma, Unresectable, stage IIIC or metastatic, BRAF V600E mutation positive

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- QT prolongation has been reported, with an increased risk in patients with QTc interval greater than 500 milliseconds or long QT syndrome (use not recommended); monitoring recommended and reduction of dose, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Uncorrectable electrolyte abnormalities have increased risk for QT prolongation; not recommended
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, including keratoacanthomas, has been reported, with an increased risk with age greater than 65 years, prior skin cancer, and chronic sun exposure; monitoring recommended
  • -- New primary malignant melanoma has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Increased cell proliferation in BRAF wild-type cells has occurred with in vitro exposure to BRAF inhibitors; confirm BRAF V600E mutation status prior to initiation of treatment
  • -- Severe dermatologic reactions, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis, have been reported; discontinue
  • -- Mild to severe photosensitivity has been reported; dosage adjustment may be necessary
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Liver injury leading to functional hepatic impairment, coagulopathy, or other organ dysfunction may occur; monitoring recommended and reduction of dose, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Anaphylaxis and other severe hypersensitivity reactions (eg, drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms, hypotension) may occur; discontinue use permanently if such reactions occur
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Ophthalmologic reactions (eg, uveitis, blurred vision, iritis, photophobia) have been reported and may require additional treatment; monitoring recommended
  • Other:
  • -- Noncutaneous, squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- Malignancy associated with RAS activation may occur; monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Other agents known to prolong QT interval not recommended
  • -- Avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors or strong CYP3A4 inducers
  • -- Drugs predominantly metabolized by CYP1A2 that have a narrow therapeutic window not recommended
  • --The safety and efficacy with concomitant use of ipilimumab has not been established; significant elevations in liver transaminases and bilirubin have been observed in patients receiving this combination

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Alopecia (all grades, 36% to 45%; grade 3, less than 1%), Papilloma of skin (all grades, 21% to 30%; grade 3, less than 1%), Photosensitivity (all grades, 33% to 49%; grade 3, 3%), Pruritus (all grades, 23% to 30%; grade 3, 1% to 2%), Rash (all grades, 37% to 52%; grade 3, 7% to 8%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (all grades, 35% to 37%; grade 3, 2%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (all grades, 53% to 67%; grade 3, 4% to 8%)
  • Other:Fatigue (all grades, 38% to 54%; grade 3, 2% to 4%), Papilloma of skin (all grades, 21% to 30%; grade 3, less than 1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval
  • Dermatologic:Hand-foot syndrome due to cytotoxic therapy (less than 10%), Keratoacanthoma, Malignant melanoma (2.1%), Squamous cell carcinoma of skin, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (less than 10%), Toxic epidermal necrolysis (less than 10%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Other:Keratoacanthoma, Malignant melanoma (2.1%), Squamous cell carcinoma of skin

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Vemurafenib is a kinase inhibitor of some mutated forms of BRAF serine-threonine kinase, including BRAF V600E. Vemurafenib has displayed antitumor effects in cellular and animal models of melanomas with mutated BRAF V600E.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Tmax: 3 hours
  • Bioavailability: undetermined
  • Effect of food: increased AUC 5-fold, increased Cmax 2.5-fold, delayed Tmax 4 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • take with or without a meal
  • do not chew or crush
  • missed doses can be taken up to 4 hours prior to the next dose

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• confirm BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma by an FDA-approved test (cobas(R) 4800 BRAF V600 Mutation Test); prior to treatment
  • evidence of tumor response indicates efficacy
  • electrolytes, including potassium, magnesium, and calcium; prior to and following initiation of therapy, after any dose modifications, 15 days after initiation, then monthly during the first 3 months, followed by every 3 months thereafter, or more often as clinically needed
  • liver enzymes (transaminases and alkaline phosphatase) and bilirubin; prior to initiation and monthly during treatment, or as clinically indicated
  • dermatological evaluations for new primary cutaneous malignancies; prior to initiation, every 2 months while on therapy, and consider monitoring 6 months after therapy discontinuation
  • signs and symptoms of new noncutaneous squamous cell carcinomas, particularly of the head and neck; prior to initiation of therapy and periodically during treatment
  • signs and symptoms of other malignancies, including those associated with RAS activation
  • ECG; prior to and following initiation of therapy, after any dose modifications, 15 days after initiation, then monthly during the first 3 months, followed by every 3 months thereafter, or more often as clinically needed
  • signs and symptoms of uveitis; routinely

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to avoid sun exposure, wear protective clothing, and use a sunscreen as drug causes photosensitivity.
  • Advise patient to immediately report symptoms of severe dermatologic reactions (Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis) or new cutaneous malignancies.
  • Side effects may include arthralgia, rash, alopecia, fatigue, nausea, pruritus, and skin papilloma.
  • Tell patient to report cardiac symptoms of QT prolongation.
  • Counsel patient to report vision changes, photophobia, or symptoms of uveitis.
